detaileddescription.para: Used by the task that manages connecting to peers
List of peers we want to connect to as soon as possible
Used by the task that fetches sync items during synchronization

briefdescription.para: List of sync blocks we've asked for from peers but have not yet received.
List of sync blocks we've just received but haven't yet tried to process.

detaileddescription.para: List of sync blocks we've received, but can't yet process because we are still missing blocks that come earlier in the chain

memberdef.type: boost::multi_index_container< prioritized_item_id, boost::multi_index::indexed_by< boost::multi_index::ordered_unique< boost::multi_index::identity< prioritized_item_id > >, boost::multi_index::hashed_unique< boost::multi_index::tag< item_id_index >, boost::multi_index::member< prioritized_item_id, item_id,&prioritized_item_id::item >, std::hash< item_id > > > >
memberdef.definition: using graphene::net::detail::node_impl::items_to_fetch_set_type = boost::multi_index_container< prioritized_item_id, boost::multi_index::indexed_by< boost::multi_index::ordered_unique< boost::multi_index::identity<prioritized_item_id> >, boost::multi_index::hashed_unique< boost::multi_index::tag<item_id_index>, boost::multi_index::member<prioritized_item_id, item_id, &prioritized_item_id::item>, std::hash<item_id> > > >
memberdef.name: items_to_fetch_set_type

detaileddescription.para: Used by the task that fetches items during normal operation

briefdescription.para: Items to fetch sequence counter.
List of items we know another peer has and we want.
List of transactions we've recently pushed and had rejected by the delegate.

detaileddescription.para: Used by the task that advertises inventory during normal operation

briefdescription.para: List of items we have received but not yet advertised to our peers.

detaileddescription.para: We have two alternate paths through the schedule_peer_for_deletion code one that uses a mutex to prevent one fiber from adding items to the queue while another is deleting items from it, and one that doesn't. The one that doesn't is simpler and more efficient code, but we're keeping around the version that uses the mutex because it crashes, and this crash probably indicates a bug in our underlying threading code that needs fixing. To produce the bug, define USE_PEERS_TO_DELETE_MUTEX and then connect up to the network and set your desired/max connection counts high
Used by the task that checks whether addresses of seed nodes have been updated
Stores the endpoint we're listening on. This will be the same as _node_configuration.listen_endpoint, unless that endpoint was already in use.

briefdescription.para: We determine whether we're firewalled by asking other nodes. Store the result here.

detaileddescription.para: If we're behind NAT, our listening endpoint address will appear different to the rest of the world. Store it here.

briefdescription.para: A cached copy of the block interval, to avoid a thread hop to the blockchain to get the current value.

detaileddescription.para: A key automatically generated when the client is first run, stored in node_config.json. It doesn't really have much of a purpose yet, there was just some thought that we might someday have a use for nodes having a private key (sent in hello messages)

A random number generated each time the client is launched, used to prevent us from connecting to the same client multiple times (sent in hello messages). Since this was introduced after the hello_message was finalized, this is sent in the user_data field. While this shares the same underlying type as a public key, it is really just a random number.
If we have less than _desired_number_of_connections, we will try to connect with more nodes
If we have _maximum_number_of_connections or more, we will refuse any inbound connections
Retry connections to peers that have failed or rejected us this often, in seconds
How many seconds of inactivity are permitted before disconnecting a peer
Stores all connections which have not yet finished key exchange or are still sending initial handshaking messages back and forth (not yet ready to initiate syncing)
Stores fully established connections we're either syncing with or in normal operation with
Stores connections we've closed (sent closing message, not actually closed), but are still waiting for the remote end to close before we delete them
Stores connections we've closed, but are still waiting for the OS to notify us that the socket is really closed

briefdescription.para: The /n/ most recent blocks we've accepted (currently tuned to the max number of connections)
The number of items we still need to fetch while syncing.
List of all block numbers where there are hard forks.
Cache message we have received and might be required to provide to other peers via inventory requests.
Number of connections last reported to the client (to avoid sending duplicate messages)
Average network read speed in the past seconds.
Average network write speed in the past seconds.
Average network read speed in the past minutes.
Average network write speed in the past minutes.
Average network read speed in the past hours.
Average network write speed in the past hours.
Average network usage second counter.
Average network usage minute counter.

detaileddescription.para: Set to true when we begin our destructor, used to prevent us from starting new tasks while we're shutting down

briefdescription.para: Maximum number of blocks to handle at one time.
Maximum number of sync blocks to prefetch.
Maximum number of blocks per peer during syncing.
Called after a peer finishes handshaking, kicks off syncing.

memberdef.argsstring: (peer_connection *originating_peer, const std::string &reason_for_disconnect, bool caused_by_error=false, const fc::oexception &additional_data=fc::oexception())
memberdef.name: disconnect_from_peer

node.label: std::unordered_set< graphene::net::item_id, std::hash< graphene::net::item_id >, std::equal_to< graphene::net::item_id > >
